dialogues.speaker: JEWELRY STORE
dialogues.text: (Not the one where Mariette bought her bag.) Shooting fro inside store through window toward street. In front of  window appears Major. He looks, sour and depressed, at th window display. Camera moves with him as he enters shop a goes to counter. Camera pulls back, and now we discover  FranГ§ois at the counter. Both look straight ahead; they  don't see each other yet. Clerk enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Major) Yes, m'sieu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to have--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees FranГ§ois, and FranГ§ois sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Good morning, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Good morning.  (Stuttering; to clerk.)  I'd-I'd-I'd like to look at some  cuff links.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, m'sieu. Clerk goes. Major ignores FranГ§ois. FranГ§ois smiles,  ironical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with feigned innocence) Nice day, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunts) Umm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking fine, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Now see here, my good man. I've had  just about enough of your insulting   remarks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another clerk enters.  He puts several handbags on counte for FranГ§ois. FranГ§ois regards them smilingly. Major is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on cheap hotel in suburb of Paris, shooting up from stree Sign reads Paris-Astor Hotel. Camera pans down. In entran doorway, the bellboy--on his cap: Paris-Astor Hotel-- shabbily dressed, leaning lazily against door, bag of  cherries in hand. He eats and spits the stones into stree with a minimum of energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily, in negligee, lying on couch, face covered by newspa she is reading while she has breakfast, which is on a lit table beside her. The dishes are clean but cheap looking. Lily lowers the paper and looks slyly up. She sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston, in dressing gown, sitting in armchair, reading a  newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches Gaston, looks down to table, back at Gaston.  She wants to put something over without being seen-- something important. Now, quick, she decides to do it, co what may. She picks up a French roll--still watching him- dunks it in the coffee, takes a hurried bite, and  disappears again behind paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from the paper) I don't agree with this review at  all. I thought Martini's singing  was adequate, but to call him a  great singer--ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still reading her paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) I always liked him. Especially last  year in Munich ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops paper) Last year? It can't be that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops paper) Yes! Don't you remember the day you  took that Chinese vase from the  Royal Palace  (with tenderness)  and made it into a lamp for my night  table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her with emotion, gets up, and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston sits close to her, caresses her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the lamp, I remember the  night table, and I remember the  night.  (They kiss.)  Everything will be all right again.  (As he gets up; with a  valiant little smile.)  Prosperity is just around the corner! He goes out of the picture. Lily smiles after him with to confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston returns, sits, picks up paper, resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at her paper. Suddenly she stares at something on the pag She leaps to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paper in hand, followed by camera, she goes to the bureau opens a drawer, and takes out Mariette's handbag. She loo at the bag, rereads the item in the paper, looks back aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, he gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by camera, she hastens to Gaston, hands him the  paper, points to the item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large classified ad with headline: Handbag Lost--Twenty Thousand Francs Reward. Before we can read the rest, came moves close to the headline. Under the insert, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The description fits. That's our  bag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston has finished reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand francs ... If we  sold it we'd get--  (He takes the bag from  Lily, examines it like  an expert.)  Well, it's worth forty thousand at  the most. She paid probably sixty  thousand. When we sell it ... I'd  say five thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, then let's be honest and  return it to the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And take the twenty thousand francs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with sudden emotion) Sweetheart, what day is today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fourteenth of May.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tomorrow is the fifteenth. And  the day after tomorrow--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not knowing what he wants) The six--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She catches Gaston's eye. Her face lights up. Very tender she embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go to Venice, to the same hotel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (romantically) We'll take the Royal Suite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two fifty-three, five--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven and nine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll celebrate the second  anniversary of the day we didn't get  married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling! They kiss. After they have held the embrace a few moments we hear a knock  the door. They look toward the door, hid the handbag instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porter comes in, carrying a pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting them on the floor) Your shoes, Professor Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he goes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Their embrace continues. They look at each other dreamil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette and an elderly woman who has seen better days. H clothes, once elegant, now are shabby. She is unwrapping package as camera moves toward both to a close shot. She  takes out a handbag which also seen better days, holds it toward Mariette pathetically. Mariette responds with a  kindly look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry, but that's not the  bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restraining a sob) I know it isn't. But it's pretty-- isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) Very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear phone ring. Mariette, annoyed at the interruption goes out of the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette enters, picks up phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ... Yes .. . Where did you  find the bag?  (Amused.)  Where?  (Even more amused.)  Where? What?  (Smiling broadly.)  What was in it?  (With a change of  expression, outraged.)  How dare you!  (She slams down  receiver.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: bag in hand, with patient hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at phone. Her expression softens. Followed by camera, she goes to woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't have any use for it?  (Mariette hesitates.)  You see, I have another bag, and I  really don't need this. So, if you'd  like to buy it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette sees tears in the woman's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into drawer  of nearby table) Would two hundred francs be sufficient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is much more  than she expected) Yes, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette hands her the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) Oh, thank you, madame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes out of picture toward door. Mariette looks after her with compassion, which is broken by the ringing phone Increasingly annoyed, she goes to phone, newly purchased  bag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette enters edgily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ... Yes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tosses handbag out of picture.

dialogues.speaker: ARMCHAIR
dialogues.text: Bag falls on armchair into an assortment of several other bags. Mariette must have been buying bags for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Yes, this is Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the phone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Yes, I lost my bag. Yes. Last  night at the opera ... No, no, I  don't want to buy a piano!  (She hangs up angrily.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting from the direction of the living room toward the house entrance door. Hall is filled with men and women,  some well dressed, some shabby. Some carry packages. Seve women hold, each, two "found" bags. One woman carries a  crying baby. Butler's voice comes behind the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next, please. A young Russian Bolshevik, unshaven, with bushy hair, mov toward camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at open door. Bolshevik enters, followed by butler, who  shuts door behind them as Bolshevik goes to Mariette.  During all this, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... No, it was not insured. But  right now it's too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (Bolshevik enters.)  I may lose it again? But I haven't  found it yet! I'm sorry. Goodbye!  (She turns toward  Bolshevik distracted)  Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Russian accent) So you lost a handbag, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it had diamonds in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And diamonds in the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diamonds all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, have you found it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) No!  (Raising his arm  like a prophet.)  But let me tell you--any woman who  spends a fortune in times like these  for a handbag--phooey, phooey,  phooey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butler enters officiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bolshevik) I must ask you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing butler aside) And as Trotsky said--  (in Russian)  "Any woman who spends a fortune for  a silk purse is a sow's ear."  (In English.)  And that goes for you, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to hall. While Bolshevik is ranting, it opens; Gaston  enters briskly with an authoritative air, shuts door behi him.

dialogues.speaker: MARIETTE, BOLSHEVIK, AND BUTLER
dialogues.text: Mariette is startled; she doesn't know who or what the  gentleman is. Bolshevik is frightened. Butler is  momentarily nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps forward commandingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston goes to Bolshevik, puts his arm patronizingly on h shoulder, and tells him politely but emphatically, in  Russian, to leave. Bolshevik makes a protesting remark.  Gaston tells him vigorously and effectively to scram. Cow the Bolshevik goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butler, recuperated and full of dignity, opens door to th hall. Bolshevik appears, turns to Mariette and Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a final outburst) Phooey! Phooey! And--  (Looking for another word but failing to find it;  twice as loud.)  Phooey!  Butler shoves him out, follows, shuts door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette and Gaston. Mariette is more bewildered by Gasto than by the Bolshevik.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking after the  departed man) His phooey is worse than his bite.  (Turning to Mariette.)  I must apologize for entering  unannounced. If I am not mistaken,  Madame Colet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be good enough to look at  this bag, madame?  (He brings the bag  forth, hands it to  Mariette.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with instant and  joyful recognition)  That's it! Yes, that's it! ...  Jacques!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens and butler enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismiss all the people in the hall.  The bag has been found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jacques. Call up the major and  tell him-- No, don't call him. Let  him keep on searching! And Jacques--  (Phone rings. Mariette  picks up receiver and  speaks before the other  party can speak.)  Sorry--the bag's been found.  (She hangs up.)  And Jacques--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Cohen, Cohen, Ginsburg, and  Renault. Give my thanks to M'sieu  Renault.  (In high spirits.)  Thank them all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear door closing. Mariette looks happily at bag, turn to Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She discovers that Gaston is no longer standing beside he She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful Chinese vase on a table. Gaston, looking at  vase with appraising eye, is absorbed, unaware that  Mariette has addressed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes toward Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: still studying the vase. Mariette appears. He turns to he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) Where did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the main staircase in the  opera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you go to the left. There's a  landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you go into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as you leave the foyer, there is  a little niche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that niche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in that niche, there is a  statue of Venus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irrelevantly) You like that statue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) Not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.  (Without any transition.)  That's where I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (naively, not suspicious) I don't know how I could have lost  it there.  I was nowhere near that  niche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... That's strange. Maybe--are  you sure this is your bag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little nettled) Of course it is! Are you doubting  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (polite but precise) Not in the least, madame. But you  see, it's a very expensive bag--one  has to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-annoyed, half-laughing,  and a little conceited) Well--I am Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urbanely) And I am M'sieu Laval--if you will  allow me to introduce myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette is perplexed. Their relationship has somehow bee transformed. She is uncertain. Then she yields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a little laugh;  extending her hand) Well--how do you do, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pleasure is mine, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends over and kisses her hand. Camera goes quickly to close-up of a beautiful diamond ring. As he kisses the ha Gaston's eye appraises the ring.

dialogues.speaker: STREET IN PARIS
dialogues.text: FranГ§ois, package under arm, walking. It is apparent tha he has purchased the handbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at table. Gaston has just opened the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With the air of an honest  man taking inventory) One purse--  (shaking it)  empty. One vanity case--  (opening it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But really, m'sieu, this isn't  necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Madame Colet, I believe in  doing things correctly. Shall we  continue?  (He empties the bag.)  Two hairpins, one cigarette lighter,  one box of real matches, and-- Oh,  yes, this letter from Major--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh! You didn't read it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't be embarrassed, madame.  A lady as charming as you would, and  should, get love letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed and flattered) M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one suggestion, madame.  (Shaking his head.)  Not the major.  (Mariette looks startled,  as if to say, "How did  you know?")  I don't  mind his grammatical  mistakes. I'll overlook his bad  punctuation. But the letter has no  mystery--no bouquet--no ...  (Changing the subject,  taking a lipstick out  of bag.)  And one lipstick ...  (Reading markings on  bottom; disapproving.)  Scarlet number four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your skin, I prefer crimson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now on a vital theme) Too much blue in crimson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you need!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no!  (She sits on couch.  He sits beside her.)  I disagree with you completely! I  tried it once--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shade of powder do you use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peaches and cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting for her life) Do you realize I have light eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Madame Colet, that's a matter  of eye shadow. I can straighten that  out in two seconds. We hear a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed at interruption) Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butler comes in, shuts door quickly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a sour expression) The major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On couch. She makes a gesture of exasperation. So does  Gaston. They look at each other helplessly. Then Gaston  takes charge. He rises and goes toward butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at living room door. Major stands waiting. Door opens;  butler comes out, followed briskly by Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before Major can speak) I'm sorry, m'sieu, but Madame had  better not see anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major stares blankly. He never saw Gaston before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, the bag has just been  found, and the reaction of relief  from her former excitement and  strain is just a little too much  for her. It's not very serious, but  just the same we'd better not take  any chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (assuming Gaston  is a physician) Just as you say, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Major.  (Goes back toward  living room.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera goes with Major toward entrance door. Major  looks crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: in front of Mariette's house. FranГ§ois, followed by came goes to the door, rings bell. Door is opened by butler, a Major comes out, butler remaining in doorway. Major and  FranГ§ois stare at each other. Major looks pointedly at  FranГ§ois's package. Then Major turns to butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacques, has the bag been found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major turns with bright smile to FranГ§ois, who looks glu and glances instinctively at his package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Madame feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Major. Major is still looking at the unhappy FranГ§ois and havin the time of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Madame seeing anybody this  afternoon, this evening, or even  tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may shut the door, Jacques. Butler closes door. FranГ§ois, miserable, turns away from Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. that leaves you holding the  bag. Goodbye! Major lifts his hat, goes out of picture to right. FranГ§ looks after him angrily, then goes out of picture to left

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston and Mariette. There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Well, I think I'd better be going.  Goodbye, Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Goodbye, M'sieu La-- Oh, yes ...  This is a rather delicate matter and  I don't want to ... You see, if you  read my advertisement carefully, you  must have noticed that there was ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, madame, it  embarrasses you to offer me the  twenty thousand francs reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be embarrassed, madame. I'll  take it. I need the money. I wish I  were in a position to ignore the  whole matter. But you know, madame,  the stock market, bank crash ... To  make a long story short--a member  of the nouveaux poor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him sympathetically) Then I'm glad I lost the bag! I'll  write you the check immediately.  (Followed by camera, she goes.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at staircase. Coming from living room, Mariette goes up t stairs, followed by camera. At first landing, as Mariette reaches door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Colet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning)  Yes, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: GASTON BELOW
dialogues.text: Shooting down from her angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know my first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. What is it? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by camera, he runs up stairs. At the landing, he goes close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering ardently) Gaston! She looks at him with a confused smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still ardently) And do you know what I'd like to  have you do with that check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, curious) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionate) Make it out to cash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you like.  (She opens door and  he follows her.)

dialogues.speaker: INTO ADJOINING ELEGANT BEDROOM
dialogues.text: In foreground at desk, is Mariette. In bedroom background Gaston is seen examining a painting on the wall with the of a connoisseur. Camera moves to close-up of Mariette. S is opening and shutting drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, where can that checkbook be?  Oh, dear me, dear me! She must have  left it somewhere. It's always the  same--when you're looking for  something, you can't find it.  (She continues mumbling  and slamming drawers.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the wall, still admiring the painting. Now he draws  painting slightly away from wall and glances behind as if looking for a safe. He allows painting to drop back into  place. Followed by camera, he goes on looking around. He  stops before window, looks out, studying possible entranc and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at desk, still searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find that checkbook. I  should have discharged her six  months ago! I really don't know  what to do. Where can I look now?  (Turning to Gaston.)  M'sieu Laval, I'm very sorry, but-- She tops short. Gaston is not there. She sees:

dialogues.speaker: DOOR TO FORMER SECRETARY'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: It is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by camera, she goes to bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at open door. Mariette enters, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston is studying bed with the eye of a connoisseur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in doorway. She looks mystified. She moves toward him  lightly because:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston apparently doesn't know she is in the room. He is  still studying bed with scholarly concentration. Mariette enters, stops beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with respect for the bed) Eighteenth century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting it; impressed) Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early eighteenth century. I should  say around--seventeen thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examining headboard) Beautiful specimen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is beautiful. But I got a little  tired of sleeping in antiques, so I  gave it to my secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (specially interested as  he learns this is not  Mariette's room) Oh?  (He wants to hear more.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This used to be my secretary's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with affected nonchalance) I see. (Going very close to  headboard, touching woodwork  with expert hand.)   She must have been very happy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Too happy. That's why I discharged  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his eye caught by carving  on one of the posts) Isn't that wonderful!  (He turns to Mariette.)  You see, madame-- (He stops, noticing  something on the wall.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wall is a safe. Camera moves to close-up of safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspired) Let me tell you something, madame,  as a man who has had all kinds of  secretaries ... I wonder if she put  that checkbook in the safe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly think so. But let's look.  (She goes toward safe.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette enters, starts turning knob, lips moving silentl as she articulates numbers to herself. The camera pans he out and stops before Gaston who is now close behind her,  concentrating on the combination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turning knob back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is instinctively turning an imaginary knob, following  Mariette's pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette opens safe. Gaston takes a swift good look into  safe, but acts casual in case Mariette turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rummaging with her hand) No, no. No, it's not here. (Suddenly.)   Oh! What do you think of that?  (She brings out two crisp  packages of bank notes.)  A hundred thousand francs!  (With a half-smile.)  You know, I didn't have the  slightest idea--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (severely) But, madame, you keep a hundred  thousand francs--in your safe--at  home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) You think that's too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) No! Not enough!  (With the air of a banker.)  In times like these, when everything  is uncertain, every conservative  person should have a substantial  part of his fortune within arm's  reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding with the gravity  of a woman accepting her  banker's advice) That sounds sensible.  (She goes out of the picture,  thinking it over.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette enters, sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very sensible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston enters, sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly; an uncle) Madame Colet, I think you deserve a  scolding. First, you lose your bag--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily) Then I mislay my checkbook--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you use the wrong lipstick--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost laughing) And how I handle my money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's disgraceful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a flirtatious look) Tell me, M'sieu Laval, what else is  wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything! ... Madame Colet, if I  were your father-- (with a smile)  which, fortunately, I am not--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coquettish) Ye-es?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you made any attempt to handle  your own business affairs, I would  give you a good spanking--in a  business way, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (complete change of  expression; businesslike) What would you do if you were my  secretary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hired!

dialogues.speaker: BOARD OF DIRECTORS ROOM
dialogues.text: Camera moves along the table in close shots of members of the board. An excited murmur runs along the table. Camera stops in front of M. Giron, the chairman, who is talking the man beside him. Now he turns to opposite end of table rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking for the board of directors as well as myself, if you insist, in  times like these, on cutting the  fees of the board of directors, then  we resign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at opposite end. He gets up with an air of authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking for Madame Colet as well as  myself--resign!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haughtily) Very well!  (He hesitates.)  We'll think it over, M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of insurance agent at his desk. He is looking over Mme.  Colet's policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, M'sieu Laval, as for Madame  Colet's life insurance, it totals  one million francs. There is five  hundred thousand fire insurance and  four hundred thousand against  burglary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a different suit. He begins to calculate with his  fingers and murmurs figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Then we'd better increase the  burglary insurance to eight hundred  and fifty thousand francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily; with a little bow) Thank you, M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the kitchen. Big, fat, motherly looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No potatoes, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In still another suit. He is standing, looking stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No potatoes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, M'sieu Laval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering a question) No, M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fluffy, pretty little maid in Gaston's bedroom, holding duster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing naughty) Maybe, M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Mariette's feet and legs in gymnasium outfit, shooting down on an angle. Feet rise and camera follows movement  arc-wise, comes to rest on Mariette's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the position) Is this what you mean, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: erect in sweater, arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely, Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston in doorway to his office. Evening; lights are on.  He wears a dark business suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coaxingly) Now, M'sieu Laval, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankly, madame, I'm too tired.

dialogues.speaker: UPPER STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: from Gaston's viewpoint. Mariette, in evening dress, is n landing. From downstairs, the music of a tango and laught of guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to come down and  join the party? Just a little tango --no? Oh, you with your messy old  papers and contracts and money-money -money--all those uninteresting  things!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very interesting to me,  madame. And somebody in this house  should worry about money. No,  madame, really, I have to be up  early in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Gaston at window, walking up and down dictating, follo by camera. We hear click of a typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New paragraph. Furthermore, it is  Madame's wish--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typing away at an appropriate desk is none other than our Lily. She is demure in a little blouse and skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --that while half of the interest  shall be deposited as usual in  Madame's account--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the other half, contrary to  custom, shall be delivered in cash  into Madame's personal custody.  (Followed by camera, he  goes to Lily and takes  her in his arms.)  Darling, that means that on the  second of June we'll have eight  hundred and fifty thousand francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ecstatically) And her jewelry is worth a fortune!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No jewelry! Hands off jewelry! If  we're broke--all right. I might  pick up a million-franc necklace.  But in times like these when we're  doing a cash business--why take a  chance on jewelry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily gets up, goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the way a wife talks  to a husband when she  wants something special) I know you're awfully busy, and I  don't like to trouble you. But she  has one little necklace--you know,  that one with the seed pearls? It's  so quiet and simple. It would go  just beautifully with my neck.  Gaston takes her in his arms, moved. They kiss. There is knock at the door. They leap into employer and employee  positions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in!

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Butler enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieu Laval, Madame would like to  talk to Mademoiselle Gautier for a  moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Jacques.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear door close as butler goes. Lily turns to Gaston. looks her over, straightens her hair a little, then pulls the zipper on her blouse high up to the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette in bed. Breakfast table. She is reading a magazi Knock on door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down magazine) Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily enters. She is now wearing glasses. (Under no  circumstances shall her appearance be exaggerated. Lily i playing the part of a modest, polite little  secretary.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning,  madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, mademoiselle.  (She makes a gesture  inviting Lily to come  closer.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches Mariette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in bed. Lily enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating a chair) Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily sits on a small chair by the bed. Breakfast table is between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy at the  breakfast tray) You've had your breakfast--oh,  but of course you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame. You see, I have to get  up very early.  (Chattering.) My little brother goes to school--  (With controlled pathos.)  You see, Mother is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring her own coffee;  making conversation) Yes, that's the trouble with  mothers. First you get to like them  and then they die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily nods sad agreement. Her glance drops to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a diamond ring on floor by bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at ring with undisguised desire for an instant. Then she reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily's hand lifts ring from floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing that she has been observed, Lily hands ring to  Mariette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.  With indifference she throws it over toward night table o the other side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT TABLE
dialogues.text: A little jewel box, open. The ring falls in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks toward the jewel box with regret, fingers itchi She pulls herself together and sits on her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette is just about to reach for the cream. Lily, quic and polite, takes the cream pitcher and pours for Mariett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you! ... Now, mademoiselle,  the reason I asked you to come--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two lumps, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!  (Lily puts sugar  in coffee.)  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a spoon) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette nods graciously. Lily stirs the coffee. Then she sits and resolutely puts her hands under again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts cup, sips coffee. She looks over at Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking downward modestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She watches Lily a moment to make sure she is not looking Then she dunks a roll in the coffee and takes a quick bit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mademoiselle Gautier--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see--  (She has just picked up  some potato a la Julienne --thinly shredded, noodle-like  and crisp--on her fork. Then  she speaks furtively as she  suddenly remembers.)  Oh, not a word to M'sieu Laval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in a whisper) Potatoes. He doesn't want me to eat  them--  (with a little laugh)  and naturally I don't want to upset  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a poisonous  little giggle) Naturally not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly her giggle dies out, and she looks at Mariette wit sly contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Uh--mademoiselle--in the short  time you have been M'sieu Laval's  secretary, have you noticed any  change in him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on guard) Well--uh--yes and no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To me he seems rather nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous?  (She takes a chance.)  Um-hum. He smokes too much!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he works too much.  (Lily nods with  great relief.)  He's chained to his desk. Too much  detail. Now, if you could take over  some of his work--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deadly sweetness) So he wouldn't be confined so much  to his office--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently pleased) Yes! And he would have a little  more time for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all the really important  things--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I'll do my best, madame, even if I  have to work every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Oh, no, no, no, no, my dear child!  That's ridiculous. You go home as  usual--five o'clock every day. Now  I'm going to be a little bit of a  tyrant--I insist. It'll be nice for  your little brother, too. Five  o'clock--remember!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, madame. Thank you.  (She starts to leave.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily opens door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, my dear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns) Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is your salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in times like these most  people are cutting salaries, but  suppose we say, in your case,  three hundred and fifty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, madame, you're just too sweet  for words!  (She goes, shutting door.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: close to door. Gaston is pacing up and down. Lily enters, quickly closes door behind her. She takes off her glasses She is seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what does she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You! And she's willing to pay as  high as fifty francs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (violently) But it's not enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette, still in bed, talking into phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, FranГ§ois, don't be silly. I  have nothing against you ... Oh, no,  that's all forgotten ... What? ... Not this week, FranГ§ois ...  (Happily.)  Business, FranГ§ois, business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which during the scene moves to a closer shot of Gaston a Lily. As we pick them up both are pacing up and down at t height of unpleasantness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking like a child. You  know exactly what we're here for  and what it's all about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping) This woman has more than jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing it) Ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever take a good look at  her--uh--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all right, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. And what of it?  (Going close to Lily;  with conviction) Let me tell you something: so far  as I'm concerned, her whole sex  appeal is in that safe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him a moment;  suddenly fearful) Gaston. Let's open it--right now!  Let's get away from here!  (With great unhappiness;  holding back her tears.)  I don't like this place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her in his arms) Oh, no, darling. There's more sex  appeal coming on the first of the  month.  It's only ten days ...   (Rolling it on  his tongue.)  Eight hundred and fifty thousand  francs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clinging to him) Darling, remember you're Gaston  Monescu. You're a crook. I want you  as a crook. I love you as a crook.  I worship you as a crook. Steal,  swindle, rob--but don't become one  of those useless, good-for-nothing  gigolos!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of clock on desk. It is 5 P.M. We hear five chimes. Again this shot of clock:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Gaston darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear sound of a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I leave you alone with that  lady--but if you behave like a   gentleman--   (Slowly.)   I'll break your neck!   (With tenderness.)  Goodbye, darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear door open, close, and the sounds of Gaston  returning from the door, humming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads 5:12. We hear a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of the door opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending surprise  at not seeing Lily) Oh, M'sieu Laval ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madame Colet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Mademoiselle Gautier gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--uh--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With feigned regret) Oh, that's too bad. You see, I  wanted her to do something.  Well,  I guess I'll have to do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask her to ask you if  you'd be good enough to go out to  dinner with me tonight. We hear her laugh. He joins her. As the laugh gets louder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five past nine. Light is different, room being almost in  darkness. We hear phone ring several times. Nobody answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten to eleven. So dark that we can barely see the hands.  From outside, faint voices. We hear door open, and a bar light falls across clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Madame Colet. And let  me tell you again--you dance like a  dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly) Oh, no, it's the way you lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, madame, it's the way you follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, m'sieu!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the evening is still young.  Let's go down to the living room and  talk it over.  (Cheating by an hour.)  It's only ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. He apparently joins her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of a different, more decorative clock on mantel. Hands st at eleven. As clock strikes eleven, with dainty, rapid  chimes, pan along one side, following mantel, until clock out of picture, and we see two half-empty champagne glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open window frames a view of garden. Foreground is dark.  Above trees, a church steeple with a clock large enough s that we can read the time. It is twelve. As we hear, in  splendid tones and a slower rhythm, the tolling of midnig pan over to the side. Steeple is out of picture and full  moon comes in.

dialogues.speaker: HALL UPPER END OF STAIRS
dialogues.text: Close shot of hall clock near Mariette's bedroom door. Ha indicate the hour of two, and deep tones strike the hour. Apparently there is only a dim light. Camera pans to door Mariette's bedroom. In half-open doorway stands Mariette, evening dress, looking toward office door, eyes languorou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly)  Good night, M'sieu Laval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In half-open doorway stands Gaston, white tie and tails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low tone) Good night, Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one end, at her open bedroom door, is Mariette. At oth end, as we have seen, is Gaston. They look at each other a vibrant moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (since nothing happens; sadly) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also sad) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette goes into her room, closes door. Gaston stands a moment in his doorway, undecided. Then, with a decisive a he goes halfway toward Mariette's door. He stops abruptly the one light, a lamp on the wall. He turns it out. Then goes back to his office-bedroom slowly. Camera moves clos to him and up to his door. He goes in, shuts door, and we hear the lock click from inside. Camera pans quickly to  Mariette's door. We hear similar click.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: A large window, consisting of four or five framed units,  fronts on a terraced garden in which a small informal par is underway.  Close shot of the first frame, showing part of garden and terrace. Windows are shut; we cannot hear what is going o Beyond window, on terrace: a group of society people,  teacups, butler serving cakes from tray. Mariette comes f garden to join group, a cordial hostess As she moves her is caught elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS QUICKLY to the last window frame, following h glance, and stops before Gaston and two very attractive  young ladies who seem delighted at what he is saying.  Mariette comes quickly into the picture and, pretending s wants to introduce him to someone else, takes Gaston from his dangerous companions.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MOVES
dialogues.text: back along window with them. As soon as the two young lad are out of the picture, Mariette brings Gaston intimately close toward window and camera. (Assumption is that livin room is empty and no one can see them from behind camera. Charmingly and with a twinkle in her eye, she reprimands  him, in a guarded whisper, about flirting. He answers and apparently says something that makes her laugh, disarming her. With a sudden return to party manner, she moves with him along the framed windows. Camera goes with them as sh introduces him to a few little groups. By this time, they are back in the first window frame, and now they move out of picture.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA CONTINUES
dialogues.text: past window and discloses inside corner of living room. I a chair, sitting stiffly as if in a waiting room, is M.  Giron, the chairman of the board, briefcase on knees,  flower in buttonhole. He seems in a bad mood--apparently  the financial cut hasn't agreed with him. We hear a door  opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieu Giron, Madame will be with  you presently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Jacques.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear door closing. Giron, irritated, gets up and,  followed by camera, goes toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at window shooting into living room. Giron comes toward  window and looks into garden. His face gets stern and ang as he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giron's view, of Gaston and the major, animatedly convers Camera angle must be so that Gaston is more prominent, th giving impression that Giron's attention is focused on  Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, my dear Major. There's a  limit to what you can do with  infantry. If have you the proper  artillery backing, I would say-- maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: toward window. Behind window stands Giron, muttering  imprecations under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no! I disagree with you  absolutely. That's the trouble with  you artillery men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a minute, Major--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Captain, I tell you-- Mariette comes into the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Major, you mustn't monopolize  M'sieu Laval.  (To Gaston.)  Please!  (She leads Gaston away,  camera with them. They  stop before another group.  She introduces Gaston.)  May I present M'sieu Laval? Madame  Chotard, Madame Leconte, Madame  Poncelet.  (Camera moves with them  to a lady and a gentleman.)  Madame Rudaux, M'sieu Legrand-- M'sieu Laval.  (They move to FranГ§ois  and a lady.)  M'sieu Laval--Madame Boucher. M'sieu  Filiba.  (FranГ§ois bows, not  recognizing Gaston.  Camera moves along  with them to others.)  M'sieu Laval--Madame Jeantaud,  M'sieu Gentil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston, his back to camera, bows politely; then suddenly- a second "take"--he looks over his shoulder toward FranГ§ It is apparent he has recognized FranГ§ois. Mariette move Gaston along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's that M'sieu Laval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laval? Who is M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She says he's her  secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FranГ§ois turns and looks searchingly at Gaston, who has  paused with Mariette at another group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? ... So!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he says he is her secretary. Maybe  I'm wrong--maybe he is her secretary.  (She laughs cynically.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette has apparently left the last group, and he remai The others, at the moment, are busy with tea and cakes; n one talks. Gaston, back to camera, steals another look ov his shoulder at FranГ§ois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from Gaston's viewpoint. He is staring at this new and  dubious figure in Mariette's life--Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with the group. He sees that FranГ§ois is staring at him, becomes a little uncomfortable. With sudden decision, he  turns to the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, please.  Followed by camera, he steps over to FranГ§ois. Camera st in a close shot on Gaston, FranГ§ois, and lady. Gaston bo to lady, faces FranГ§ois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, m'sieu, but I have the  feeling we have met somewhere  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snobbish, polite) I'm sorry, but I don't seem to  recall the occasion. No, I'm  afraid ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (courteously) Well--then it must be my mistake.  (Bowing.)  I beg your pardon.  He smiles, ignoring the snub, as FranГ§ois stands with  frozen superiority. Gaston goes. FranГ§ois looks after hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the lady) That man never met me, and he knows  it. Trying to make social  connections!

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM MARIETTE AND GIRON
dialogues.text: On a table is a pile of business papers and an empty  briefcase. Giron has fountain pen in his hand, ready to  turn it over to Mariette for signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a despairing  little laugh) But my dear M'sieu Giron, I'm  having a tea party. Must I be  bothered with all these papers now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, madame, but there are  still certain matters which I think  you should attend to yourself. And  I, personally, would not care to  refer them to--to--  (He hesitates.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giron doesn't answer. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With dignity) Madame Colet, I've enjoyed the  confidence of your family for more  than forty years.  (With great feeling.) I was a school friend of your  husband's ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his white hair,  which tells the whole story  of her marriage; grimly) I know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, let me ask you: Who is  M'sieu Laval, anyhow? Where does he  come from? What is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crisply) He is my secretary! I hope that  answers all your questions, M'sieu  Giron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You know what Paris is saying  about the Countess Falconier and  her chauffeur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged--furious, then  icy; turning to door) Jacques!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens; butler enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask M'sieu Laval if he will be  good enough to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, madame.  We hear the door closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of lady and FranГ§ois at a table. FranГ§ois is very fidge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, please. Please calm yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm like that--I can't help it! I  know I never met that man, and yet-- (Looking in Gaston's  direction.)  Laval, Laval ... You know, if I  like a man, I remember him. And if  I don't like a man, I never forget  him. In a nutshell, madame, it's  little things like that that drive  me crazy! Excuse me!  (He gets up and walks  out of the picture.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in garden. He is about to join another group when FranГ§o stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieu Laval ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, M'sieu Filiba?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see--  (He stops to look Gaston  over from all angles,  tortured with uncertainty.  Shaking his head and  smiling.)  No, no! And yet--  (He looks at Gaston  intently again.)  Did I--did--now where could we have-- They are interrupted by entrance of butler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gaston) Pardon me, m'sieu. Madame Colet  would like to see you in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once, Jacques.  (To FranГ§ois.)  We'll continue later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. FranГ§ois now has jealousy added to his confused suspicion. As he glares after Gaston the major enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now see here, my good man, let's  face the facts. I'm having a dinner  party, and one man turned me down  at the last minute.  (Very cutting.)  Have you a dinner jacket?  (FranГ§ois stiffens.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giron and Mariette. The situation is tense. Gaston enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With a bow) Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be good enough to run  through these papers with M'sieu  Giron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Giron, sharply) And so will M'sieu Giron.  Giron bows. Mariette turns.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: Mariette goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment the men eye each other. Gaston smiles, but  Giron maintains a frigid face. Gaston calmly takes the  papers, sits, and starts to go over the figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieu Laval, there are several  things I've wanted to ask you for  quite a while. I understand you are  from Marseilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to be absorbed  in the figures; absently) Um-hum ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (persistently) You must be related to the Lavals  of Marseilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With pretense of being  mildly distracted) Just a second.  He goes over the papers even more thoroughly, turns sever pages, then turns back, apparently comparing items,  muttering figures to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) I hope you find the figures correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly) I hope so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with indignation) M'sieu Laval, I have enjoyed the  confidence of this family--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) For more than forty years. So Madame told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (change of tone;  very deliberately) And I have known the Lavals of  Marseilles for more than thirty  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deaf to Giron, concentrating on figures, he turns absentl to the window and suddenly comes awake, for he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston's viewpoint. Outside window, on terrace, stands  FranГ§ois. He is staring at Gaston as if to say, "Where d I see him?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles cordially at FranГ§ois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through window. He begins to smile, then shakes head as i saying, "No, that's not the fellow." He goes out of the  picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston still smiling toward window. Now he turns back to papers and begins muttering more figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a cutting voice) M'sieu Laval, you seem to be  avoiding my questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, M'sieu Giron, seem to be  disturbing my examination of this  report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Examination! M'sieu Laval, what are  you insinuating? I have enjoyed the  confidence of this family for more  than forty years. How long have you  enjoyed Madame's confidence? Three  weeks, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Two weeks and three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nastily) Um-hum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very softly) Are you insinuating anything, M'sieu  Giron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With equal softness  and a sudden smile)  No, not at all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Well, that's fine. Then you are not  insinuating that I am avoiding  questions. And I am not insinuating  that you won't let me examine this  report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing the friendly  note; with an innocent  chuckle) I was only asking if you are related  to the Lavals of Marseilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more friendly) And I was only asking you if you  would let me examine your report  without interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a man about to  make a new friend) I don't see why any man should get  excited when he is asked about his  hometown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't see any reason for any  man getting nervous when somebody  checks over the figures of his  report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden change; enraged) Are you insinuating that this is  not an honest report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With vigor) I am only insinuating that you are  nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Nervous! Why should I be nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With deadly sincerity) I don't know, M'sieu Giron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outraged, Giron picks up the batch of papers, shakes it i Gaston's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to say that there  is anything in these figures to  make me nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston pauses, and we see his suspicion has become a  certainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a quiet smile)  No, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With quick, casual movement, Gaston takes the report from Giron's hand, drops it in desk, locks desk, and puts key his pocket. Giron is speechless, frightened to his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up; amiably) We'll keep these papers here.  (Taking Giron by the arm,  he leads him toward door.  Camera follows them from  behind.)  And tomorrow morning I'll drop in at  your office, and I'll tell you all  about the Lavals of Marseilles.  (Giron looks back over  his shoulder toward the  desk in a panic.)   And there won't be any tea party to  interrupt us!  They reach the door. He escorts Giron out, follows, close the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at a table. On table is an ashtray. FranГ§ois is sitting table, an unlighted cigarette in his hand, very thoughtfu still trying to place Gaston. He puts cigarette in his  mouth, takes a match from ashtray, which is equipped with matchbox. He lights cigarette and suddenly looks at ashtr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is made in the shape of a gondola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: staring at the gondola. We see that his mind is grappling trying to connect gondola, Venice, and Gaston. He rises,  brain working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the half-open doorway stands Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out toward street) Goodbye, M'sieu Giron!  He shuts door quickly and goes out of picture toward stai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston runs quickly up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the door. Gaston opens door, enters, closes it quickly with great excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily is typing. She is startled at Gaston's sudden entran and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at door. Followed by camera, he goes to Lily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who is here?  (There is a knock on the  door. Lily goes quickly  back to typewriter.)  Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butler opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieu Laval, M'sieu Filiba would  like very much to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a moment. We hear door shut. Lily gets up, puzzled. The name sounds slightly familiar to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filiba ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes--Filiba! Venice--Grand Hotel-- room two fifty-three--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it dawns on her) Five, seven, and nine--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  (With swift reassurance.)  Now don't worry!  Followed by camera, he hastens out, closing door behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston comes quickly down, goes out toward entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of FranГ§ois, waiting, hat in hand, ready to leave. Gasto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to say goodbye to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Goodbye, M'sieu Filiba.  (He starts away.  FranГ§ois stops him.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before I say goodbye I want to  ask you one question: Have you ever  been in Venice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never been in Venice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ...  (Suddenly.)  Have you ever been in Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amsterdam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constantinople?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with astonishment) You've never been in Constantinople?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have been in Venice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you, Venice can't  compare with Constantinople.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you say! In  Constantinople at least you have  streets, sultans, pashas--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (up a new alley; with a  new, naughty interest) And harems ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FranГ§ois leans over and whispers a question. Gaston nods vigorously, then leans over and whispers in FranГ§ois's e FranГ§ois's eyes get bigger and bigger. The two men look each other with a big smile. FranГ§ois extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they shake;  almost singing) Well--Con-stan-ti-nople!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by camera, FranГ§ois goes toward street door, op it, then stops and turns around. His face suddenly sobers He looks at Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at foot of staircase. He bows smilingly to FranГ§ois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FranГ§ois looks searchingly at Gaston for a long moment,  then turns and departs, still puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once door is shut, there is a swift change on his face. H turns and dashes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at door. Gaston enters and, followed by camera, goes swif to desk, past Lily, who stands fearful and ready for acti straight to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Г‰ysГ©e seven, eight, nine, two.  (To Lily.)  We have to clear out.  (Into phone.)  Railroad station? Ticket office,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) He recognized you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--not yet--but--  (Into phone.)  Two tickets to Berlin--first class and sleeper--night train ... Right  ... Right ... Leave them in the  name of--Don Ignacio Fernandez ...  Right ... Thank you.  (Hangs up.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who already has got at  a telephone directory) Spanish passports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. Now the train leaves--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At twelve twenty. I know.  (She grabs phone.)  Lyons two, four, seven, one.  (Hand over mouthpiece.)  Two more days and we'd have seven  hundred and fifty thousand francs  more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll have to take what's  here. A bird in hand is worth two in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello ... Is this the Spanish  consulate? This is DoГ±a Ignacio  Fernandez.  (In Spanish.)  My husband and I are leaving tonight  for Berlin ... Is it too late to get  a visa this afternoon ... ? Thank  you, thank you.  (She hangs up. To  Gaston; in English.)  How long will it take you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Fortunately, she has a  dinner engagement tonight. I'll meet  you at the station--midnight.   (Lily hastens out.  Phone  rings. Gaston answers.)  Hello ... Yes? What? ... You found  a handbag? Well, you're three weeks  too late!  (He hangs up. Lily  swiftly returns, wearing  hat and jacket.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, see you at the Berlin Express.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, how is your German?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grossartig--kolossal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, um zwoelf Uhr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am Berliner Zug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auf wiedersehn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auf wiedersehn.  A quick kiss. She speeds out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Marchand two, nine, one, one ...  Hello ... Is this the Petit Flower  Shop? This is Don Ignacio Fernandez.  I'd like you to take five dozen  roses--deep red roses--and I'd like  you to put them in a basket and send  the basket tomorrow morning to  Madame Mariette Colet. The Madame  Colet ... Yes ... You have the  address? ... Good! And attach a  card: "In memory of the late M'sieu  Laval" . . Tomorrow morning--ten  o'clock .. . Yes. [What? ... Charge it to Madame Colet. Yes.] Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM MAJOR'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Table is for twenty-four people. Butler at table. Major  enters, half-dressed: tuxedo trousers, stiff shirt withou collar, dressing gown. Butler gives him the place cards,  already stacked in order. Major puts first card at head o table. As he does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major's hand puts down card reading Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks at second place card, smiles, puts it at next place As he does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major's hand puts down card reading Madame Colet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks at next card. Smile disappears. He gives butler a  reproving look. Followed by camera, he goes with the card other end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major's hand puts down card reading M. FranГ§ois Filiba.

dialogues.speaker: FRAN
dialogues.text: FranГ§ois, in underwear, shaving brush in one hand and sa razor in the other, sitting on edge of bathtub, still try to figure out where he saw Gaston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at door to her bedroom. Mariette, in evening gown and wra comes out. About to go downstairs, she stops. Followed by camera, she goes to office door, knocks. Door opens, and  Gaston appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very charming)  What are you going to do with my day  tomorrow, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her a moment  with real feeling, knowing  he is saying goodbye) Well, we'll have breakfast in the  garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Um-hum ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then riding together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Um-hum ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then lunch in the Bois--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a little nap--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (restrains an automatic  "together" and smiles,  a bit embarrassed) How do you like my dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning it) Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seductively) Hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvelous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closer; softly) Lipstick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaston leans to inspect her mouth; any moment they might  kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crimson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Still softer) Correct!  (After a slight pause;  extending her hand.)  Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking hand; slowly) Good night.  (He kisses her hand.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without withdrawing hand) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly letting hand drop;  in a slightly different  voice) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He remains in doorway looking after her as, followed by  camera, she goes to the staircase. When she is down a few steps:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing on steps) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in office doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you staying out late?

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: from Gaston's view. Big close-up of Mariette. She looks a him with eagerness, thinking he has amorous designs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees she misunderstood, is a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Close-up of Mariette. She misinterprets his embarrassment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot tell the truth and is so truly smitten that he  hates to lead her on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: convinced he is shyly in love with her and needs assistan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeats softly) Why do you ask, M'sieu Laval?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a helpless smile) Do I have to answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her lips form the inaudible whispered answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soundlessly)  No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in doorway. He bows, returns into office; door shuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks after him an instant, then, followed by camera, goe slowly downstairs, very happy; her love affair is coming a head. She stops. On impulse, she turns and, followed by camera, goes quickly up stairs to his office and enters,  closing door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY'S HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Lily is packing--Gaston's clothes and her own. She gaily  hums a well-known Spanish fandango.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mariette's home, including office door and door to  Mariette's bedroom. Butler comes up stairs, goes to  Mariette's door, knocks. Door to office opens and Mariett comes out, now without her wrap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Jacques?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns, puzzled to see Mariette in office doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is waiting, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't need the car, Jacques. I'm  not going.  She turns back, shuts office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazed) Very well, madame!  Followed by camera, he starts down staircase, muttering t himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door opens; Gaston comes out quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
